channel.title: The Far Side of the Sun
channel.description:
http://news.aol.com/article/nasas-twin-stereo-spacecraft-offer-look/316665 Thought that was interesting. Yay! First news topic! :eek:
(Jan. 23) - NASA's twin STEREO spacecraft are offering the first glimpse of the far side of the sun, the space agency announced today. The two spacecraft, launched Oct. 25, 2006, are beaming back over-the-horizon images "that have researchers and forecasters glued to their monitors," according to a statement.

item.title: The Far Side of the Sun
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

chassy13:

Is the sun really all that interesting? The other side probably looks almost the exact same as the other one, and it’s not like it’s going to go anywhere soon…

Yeah but it spews cosmic rays out of it some which can affect our planet, seeing the sun spewing them in our path we can determine things back on earth.

And you know how scientists are, always eager to link the suns amount of X rays to how many midgets you can fit into a phone box.

Read full topic
item.source: The Far Side of the Sun

item.title: The Far Side of the Sun
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Uhhh, I don’t do physics but if we rotate around the sun don’t we see everyside of it aleast once a year?

EDIT: ahh, read the article. They want to be able to monitor the whole sun 24/7.

Read full topic
item.source: The Far Side of the Sun
